title: Tampa
text: The map shows a clear spatial pattern in the percentage of the population with a doctorate degree across the Tampa region. The areas with the highest percentage (4-6%) are concentrated in the central and northern parts of the city, while the southern and eastern regions have lower percentages (1-3%). This suggests socioeconomic disparities in educational attainment within the Tampa metropolitan area.

title: Education in Florida
text: This map shows a heat map of bachelor’s degree attainment across the state of Florida. The map uses a color gradient from purple to yellow, where darker purple indicates lower percentages of bachelor’s degree holders (0-10%) and lighter colors including greens and yellows represent higher percentages (up to 50%). There is significant variation across the state, with some clusters of higher educational attainment corresponding to major urban areas. The panhandle region and central Florida show generally darker purple coloring, suggesting lower rates of bachelor’s degree attainment, while there are pockets of lighter colors, particularly along some coastal areas and what appear to be major metropolitan regions.

title: About
text: My name is David Kane, and I am an instructor at New College of Florida. This is the location of the GitHub repo for this project. The data for the project comes from the American Community Survey. The repo includes all the code for replicating the analysis on this website.

title: About
text:
Key Features:

Annual Data Collection: The ACS collects data every year, providing up-to-date information on population characteristics.
Detailed Topics: It covers a wide range of topics, including education, employment, income, housing, transportation, and more.
Geographic Granularity: Data is available at various geographic levels, from national and state levels down to census tracts and block groups.

title: About
text:
Importance:

Informed Decision-Making: Governments, businesses, and nonprofits use ACS data to allocate resources, plan services, and make policy decisions.
Community Insights: The survey helps identify trends and disparities in areas like poverty, education, and housing affordability.
Supplement to the Census: The ACS complements the decennial Census by providing more frequent updates on population changes.

title: About
text:
How It Works:

Sampling Method: The ACS uses a rotating sample of addresses, ensuring representation across the U.S. population.
Voluntary Participation: Selected households are required by law to respond, ensuring high-quality data.

The ACS is a critical tool for understanding the evolving needs of American communities and shaping the nation’s future.
